hotspots.label: Fossil Shell
hotspots.fact: This is a fossil — the preserved remains of a creature that lived long, long ago! Fossils like this help scientists learn about Earth's history and what living things existed thousands of years ago. This is called a **fossil** — that's when the hard parts of plants or animals turn into rock over millions of years and get preserved in the ground.

vocabulary.definition: The preserved remains or traces of ancient living things that have turned into rock over millions of years.

hotspots.label: Rock Layers
hotspots.fact: You can see different colored rocks stacked together in this pile, just like layers of a sandwich! Rocks form in layers over time, and by studying these layers, scientists can tell the age of Earth and understand how our planet has changed. The study of rock layers is called **stratigraphy** — it helps us read Earth's history like a book.

vocabulary.definition: Stacked sheets of rock that form over time, with older rocks usually at the bottom and newer rocks at the top.

hotspots.label: Weathering & Erosion
hotspots.fact: Notice how these rocks have rough, bumpy surfaces and some are worn smooth? This happens because of **weathering** — when wind, water, and weather break down rocks into smaller pieces over long periods of time. Earth is constantly changing as rocks wear away and get transported to new places!

vocabulary.definition: The slow process where rocks are broken down into smaller pieces by wind, water, ice, and weather.

hotspots.label: Mineral Formation
hotspots.fact: These rocks are made up of tiny crystals called minerals that formed deep in the Earth over millions of years! **Minerals** are the building blocks of all rocks, and each type has its own special shape, color, and hardness. Learning about minerals helps us understand what Earth is made of underneath our feet.

vocabulary.definition: Natural, solid materials with a specific chemical makeup and crystal structure that make up rocks.
